name: Hyperledger Seoul
description:
Does The Hyperledger Project have the potential to become the engine behind most successful decentralized applications and organizations created in the next 25-50 years? Absolutely!

A much better question is how, and in what new ways, can we:

a) Build decentralized applications, organizations and APIs at 10x the speed at 1/10 the cost.

b) Build situational awareness in the local community, as the convergence of decentralized applications, decentralized organizations, Artificial Intelligence and IoT brings upon us the Great Displacement of the 21st century, where the majority of workforce will be left without “conventional” jobs, forced to learn new skills and professions.

Why?

Because with HyperLedger we can.

Founders of this group believe that the Hyperledger Foundation will be the engine behind decentralization of the world, a massive economic change of the next 25-50 years.

So.... why don't we standardize and democratize the field with and around Hyperledger?

What.

We are a local micro community of those interested in advancing their knowledge of Hyperledger, its use cases and applications.

How.

Join our group for a regular dose of human interaction, conversations, smiles, food and drinks on all things Hyperledger:

• Use Cases

• Competitive Analysis of Hyperledger Startups (Distributed Apps from disruptive companies in specific vertical markets)

• How-To’s

• Interviews with individuals working at the edge of the Hyperledger project

• Reviews of tools, services and APIs offered by the Hyperledger ecosystem

• Best Practices in Application Architecture

• Do’s and Don’ts

• Application Templates

• Hackathons

• Security in the decentralized world - on the edge, on the node, in the cloud and in transit

We will learn how others solve some of the hard problems that exist in the world using Hyperledger.

Join the movement. Let’s change the world. Because with Hyperledger we can.

name: STL Web Design and Development Meetup
description:
This group is for anyone in digital product development space for the web, from the design side (UI/UX/interaction design) to full stack development focused on Node/Javascript both server-side and client-side.  Regardless of your level of expertise, we invite you to come join us for interesting talks and presentations on both design and development at each meetup on the 3rd Thursday of each month.  Share your knowledge and expertise, learn from others, and help create a shared understanding of building amazing web products from both a design and development perspective.

Each meetup will host two, 30-minute presentations; one focused on an aspect of design and the other focused on development.  We'll have food & drink, socializing and networking with others in the community, as well as great presentations and discussions.

name: Paas, Cloud enablement in Bluemix-Developers-Bangalore
description:
This is an IBM sponsored Bluemix developers meetup group. Geared towards developers, architects and enthusiasts about Bluemix, we learn about Bluemix hands on with fellow developers and Bluemix product architects(from IBM).  Our meetups are free. 

Subject Matter Experts, Developers, Researchers, IT Consultants & Beginners who want to learn what this is all about.....all are welcome!

Bluemix is an open-standard, cloud-based platform for building, managing and running applications of all types (web, mobile, Big Data Analytics, new smart devices, and so on). Capabilities include Java, mobile back end development, application monitoring, as well as capabilities from ecosystem partners and open source software all through an as-a-service model in the cloud

With Bluemix, you can code in your choice of language, such as Java, Python, Ruby, or Node, focus on running your apps and not have to worry about getting servers or installing software.

What is IBM Bluemix?

Bluemix is an implementation of IBM’s Open Cloud Architecture, leveraging Cloud Foundry to enable developers to rapidly build, deploy, and manage their cloud applications, while tapping a growing ecosystem of available services and runtime frameworks. IBM will provide services and runtimes into the ecosystem based on our extensive software portfolio

Bluemix: Making a difference in the cloud

When IBM envisioned Bluemix, we envisioned a system which would answer the needs and challenges facing developers while at the same time empowering and enabling businesses to leverage their resources in the most efficient way possible.

BlueMix Helps Build and Integrate Apps Quickly

 IBM’s new BlueMix services are designed to help businesses rapidly transform using Big Data, mobile and social technologies in the cloud. Some of the new BlueMix services include:  

Cloud Integration services to securely connect and integrate an organization’s applications and information in the cloud. Developers can use pre-defined connectors for accelerated integration, or develop custom APIs as needed to easily and securely tie back into systems of record behind their firewall. Integrated API management capabilities provide an easy mechanism to publish self-service APIs, that can be shared with the broader API economy. This allows developers to mix cloud-based PaaS, third party cloud applications, and on-premises systems behind security gateways, moving between cloud and on-premises systems in a hybrid, integrated environment.   

Internet of Things services allowing developers to register and connect networked devices such as microprocessors and embedded machine to machine sensors to the cloud, easily aggregating and reacting to data and events in real time. Organizations can build applications which efficiently manage, analyze, visualize, and interact with the massive quantities of temporal and spatial data generated by vehicles, wearables, mobile phones, cameras, computers, sensors and other intelligent devices.

Big Data and Analytics services for developers to deliver data-centric mobile, web-scale applications. With these new services, including geospatial, time series, predictive scoring, and reporting, developers can easily create sophisticated applications that provide real-time actionable insight so that organizations can predict outcomes and make better business decisions. For example, a developer could create an application that integrates sensor data, location data, weather data and usage trends from a network of equipment to identify and avoid emerging maintenance issues. In addition, new data masking, discovery and audit capabilities help developers create applications with built-in data privacy and security.

DevOps services enabling developers, IT departments and business teams with an open, integrated rapid development environment that scales from individual developers to enterprise teams. The DevOps Continuous Integration service will provide end-to-end “build” capabilities to speed changes through the development process, DevOps Mobile Quality Assurance (MQA) will help analyze user sentiment to spot problems before they go viral, and the Monitoring and Analytics service will identify application problems during development - leveraging analytics to help applications achieve availability and performance goals. In addition, DevOps will include a new RapidApp service that requires no coding, using visual tools to expand the scope of web and business applications developers can create.
 

IBM Bluemix is now in open beta

Want to get started today? You can start today by joining the open beta. Want some help in creating a Bluemix application or service? Contact jStart

next_event.name: Deep dive on IBM Watson Conversation & Discovery service

name: Red Hat Users Group - North Texas
description:
This group is focused on bringing together the Dallas Red Hat User Community for business and technical presentations, conversations and perhaps some food and drink. Membership is open to Red Hat customers, partners and people interested in Red Hat technologies.

Some of the Red Hat products are: Red Hat Enterprise Linux, OpenStack, Storage (Ceph, GlusterFS), Virtualization (ovirt, kvm), CloudForms, FeedHenry (Node.js, Apache Cordova), JBoss Fuse (Apache Camel, Fabric8), JBoss BPM (jBPM), JBoss Data Virtualization (Teiid), JBoss EAP (Wildfly), JBoss JWS (Apache Tomcat), JBoss Data Grid (Infinispan), JBoss A-MQ (Apache ActiveMQ), JBoss BRMS (Drools), OpenShift (Jenkins, Git, Kubernetes, Docker, OpenVSwitch, RHEL, RHEL Atomic).

organizer.name: Crystal Murphy
organizer.bio: I manage events for North America in the Regional Demand Center of Red Hat.

next_event.name: COME TO THE MARCH 15, 2017 RHUG KICKOFF EVENT for the 2017-2018 YEAR

name: Amagi Academy: Professional Courses and Communities
description:
As the leading academy for training, staffing, and career transitions, Amagi Academy builds thriving communities of professionals pursuing careers they love. Message us today if you're interested in attending any of our events and unlocking your potential. 


Community Events:

We host the largest and most active IT communities in the country in Manila and Cebu. You'll get to meet people of all different backgrounds and learn from expert speakers from around the world. Each of our open community events are free and open to the public.

Manila JavaScript

BackEnd/DevOps Philippines

Next Money MNL

Manila Data Science & Analytics


IT Skills Workshops:

We're happy to work with students and organizations of all skill levels and backgrounds. Just send us a message, and we'll work with you to start building your bigger, brighter future.

Front-End Web Development
- Level I: HTML, CSS, CSS Frameworks, JavaScript
- Level II: ES6/ES7/ES8, jQuery, Sass, Vue.js
- Level III: ES6/ES7/ES8, React.js, Redux, Webpack, Redux-Saga

Back-End Web Development
- Level I: Ethical Hacking, Password Cracking, Session Hijacking, Deep/Dark Web
- Level II: ES6/ES7/ES8, Node.js, Express, Socket.io, Security, Scaling
- Level III: Golang, Interfaces and Dynamic Typing, Goroutines and Channels, Unit-Testing

Data Science
﻿- Level I: Python, NumPy, SciPy, Pandas, Visualizations, Web Scraping
- Level II: Statistics, Machine Learning, Model Selection, Regression, Classification, Dimensionality Reduction
- Level III: Advanced Mathematics, Deep Learning, Neural Networks, Artificial Intelligence


Relevant Job Postings from Sponsors: 
https://goo.gl/WZsg3l

next_event.name: Front-End Web - Level I [HTML, CSS, JS]

name: Lausanne Hacker Meetup
description: We are a loose group of hackers (not crackers), often readers/lovers of Hacker News, that meet regularly in Lausanne to discuss a wide area of topics like Entrepreneurship, Node.js, Fundraising, Webdesign, Apple fanboyism, FabLabs, Clojure, Start-up stories, arcane C++ optimization tricks, BitCoin, ramen profitability, … you get the idea : whatever might be hot and interesting.

name: Free Code Camp - Denver Study Group
description:
Do YOU want to become a web developer? Anyone can do it and this study group is a perfect way to get started and make it happen! (No experience necessary!)

This meetup is a study group for Denver freeCodeCampers that typically meets once a month at Galvanize in Denver. Join us for help getting started, to meet other freeCodeCampers, find people to pair program with, and to get support making your career change to becoming a Web Developer! 

freeCodeCamp.com is an free online community that anyone can join that helps you learn to code and practice by building projects for non-profits. Here's why you should join the freeCodeCamp open source community: • You'll get help in real time from our community chat rooms.

•  You'll meet up with other coders in your city.

•  You'll learn to code at your own pace, in your browser or on your phone.

•  You'll work through freCodeCamp's focused, interactive courses and tutorials.

•  You'll learn state-of-the-art full stack JavaScript technologies.

•  You'll build projects that help nonprofits carry out their missions more effectively.

•  You'll assemble a portfolio of real apps used by real people.

freeCodeCamp has well thought out, and continuously updated curriculum, and has a huge community of people working through the challenges and providing free online help. freeCodeCamp takes you step by step on your journey to learn HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript, databases, Git & GitHub, Node.js, React.js, and D3.js. They also have sections that cover responsive web design with Bootstrap, jQuery, Object Oriented and Functional programming, algorithms, JSON, API's, Ajax, Markdown, Express.js, MongoDB, HTTP, Microservices, the DOM, Chrome developer tools, Big O Notation.

next_event.name: freeCodeCamp Study Group - Learn Web Development, Self Paced, Beginners Welcome!

name: UI Interactive Design/Dev.; WebApp/Front End Best Practices
description:
Web App Front End Development & Design Best Practices is for developers that have moved beyond fundamentals of HTML, CSS, JavaScript and "mobile first" development. As a lead designer, you should know of preprocessors, such as Sass, SPA, Pug and Node.js, and maybe a bit about web components. There are plenty of communities for newbies, but this community is for more advanced people with at least a few years of professional experience and already have a github, portfolio or a website.

Some of the things we talk about great looking web apps such as: http://masons-foundation.org/post/asites/ <br>And/or best practices. And or discuss each other’s portfolios or CodePen.io.

We are trying to form a community of contributors. You can reach other members here: <br> http://gitter.im/topseed-demos/Lobby <br>And there are some examples here http://github.com/topseed/topseed-demos

Also, if you would like to present on a related topic, please do. Or if you have ideas for larger or better venues, please contact the organizers.

name: Boston Software Engineers
description:
These are not your typical software engineering events.

BSE is a community organization founded to inspire software developers by creating software focused events that bring together new ideas and emerging technologies.

Events produced by BSE cover topics like Robotics, 3D Printing, Nanotechnology, Wearable Technology, Synthetic Biology, Artificial Intelligence, Arduino, Deep Learning, and Space Travel all with a software engineering focus and perspective.  We often cover emerging technologies alongside current technologies and techniques.

Coding ability is encouraged but not required to attend our events.

Events format varies from speakers to panels, job fairs, networking, or code labs. Emerging technology topics are often mixed in with app development, HTML5, Hadoop, Python, Eclipse, JavaScript, Java, Machine Learning, HBASE, MapReduce, MongoDB, NoSQL, PHP, Agile, Ruby on Rails (RoR), Swift, iOS, Android, R, Frameworks, IDEs, OO, Cloud, Angular.JS, Node.JS, Mobile, Business Intelligence, and UI/UX.

We will begin to expand into areas of technology no local meetup groups have ever covered before. This is an exciting time for human civilization and for software.

Join BSE, attend our events, and experience it for yourself.

Code The Future.

organizer.name: Michael Latulippe
organizer.bio: Web developer, classically trained pianist, nature lover, HTML5 enthusiast, and founder of Become Noticed.

name: Free Code Camp - Boulder Study Group
description:
Do YOU want to become a web developer?  Anyone can do it and this study group is a perfect way to get started and make it happen!  (No experience necessary!)

This meetup is a study group for local Front Range freeCodeCampers that typically meets on the 1st and 3rd Saturdays of each month at Galvanize in Boulder, 9am -Noon. Join us for help getting started, to meet other freeCodeCampers, find people to pair program with, and to get support making your career change to becoming a Web Developer!

freeCodeCamp.com is an free online community that anyone can join that helps you learn to code and practice by building projects for non-profits. Here's why you should join the freeCodeCamp open source community: 

• You'll get help in real time from our community chat rooms.

•  You'll meet up with other coders in your city.

•  You'll learn to code at your own pace, in your browser or on your phone.

•  You'll work through freCodeCamp's focused, interactive courses and tutorials.

•  You'll learn state-of-the-art full stack JavaScript technologies.

•  You'll build projects that help nonprofits carry out their missions more effectively.

•  You'll assemble a portfolio of real apps used by real people.

freeCodeCamp has well thought out, and continuously updated curriculum, and has a huge community of people working through the challenges and providing free online help.

freeCodeCamp takes you step by step on your journey to learn HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript, databases, Git & GitHub, Node.js, React.js, and D3.js.  They also have sections that cover responsive web design with Bootstrap, jQuery, Object Oriented and Functional programming, algorithms, JSON, API's, Ajax, Markdown, Express.js, MongoDB, HTTP, Microservices, the DOM, Chrome developer tools, Big O Notation.

Future freeCodeCamp topics include: SASS, accessibility,  Agile software development, more computer science topics, more data visualization topics, embedded systems, internet of things (IoT), game development, machine learning, mobile JavaScript development, DevOps, software engineering principals, statistics, user experience design (UX), and visual design.

There are also sections at freeCodeCamp.com dedicated to Coding Interview Preparation and Mock Interviews.

They have a Medium publication, YouTube channel, GitHub repository, LinkedIn university page, Twitter feed, Facebook page, Subreddit, an active online forum, and realtime chat rooms.

Episode 204 of JavaScript Jabber podcast has an nice interview with freeCodeCamp's creator, Quincy Larson. 

Get Started with freeCodeCamp now and RSVP for our next study group meetup!

organizer.name: Steve Witman
organizer.bio:
Ruby on Rails, JavaScript, Angular developer.

Free Code Camp - Boulder Study Group meetup organizer
BoulderCODE+ meetup organizer

next_event.name: FreeCodeCamp Study Group - Learn Web Development, Self Paced, Beginners Welcome!

name: Computer Graphics on the Web
description: We’re a bunch of programmers, designers, artists and animators who want to use the latest goodness such as WebGL, Node.js, Javascript and HTML5 to make eye-popping animations. The web has matured enough to support a great deal to allow real-time computer graphics running natively in the browser. Come and wean yourself off Flash and write stuff directly on the web. Meet like-minded graphics person who loves web technology. With the new tools, it’s waaaay easier than you think.

name: Tech Confluence
description:
Tech Confluence is a once a month meetup of developers, designers and generally brilliant people in downtown Denver to present and discuss software related topics. The focus is primarily on web and mobile development and design.

Thanks to our awesome hosts, Pivotal's Pivotal Tracker team.

Past talks have included:

Agile process, Node.js, Redis, OpenColorado.org, Pair programming, Backbone.js, Remote Pairing, CSS media queries, Google Prediction API, Integrated Design & Dev, Agile Testing,

Pair Programming, Multi-Variate Testing with Xander, Creating a Bastion Server; Open source licensing, Increasing transparency, Amazon Web Services, Spritely, Information Design,

Android with Phonegap, Consumer Virtual Reality, Lexing and Parsing, Intro to Clojure, Amazon Authentication, 3D Printing, MongoDB, Apache Pig, CouchDB, BigQuery, S3, Mahout,

Regression Analysis, Yoga at your desk, Writing Better Bug Reports, Storm, Who Tests and Why, Mysql Schema Changes, Sharing Tests between Apps.

Applying Regression, VI tips and tricks, Designing APIs, Intern Diaries, Chrome debugger tips, Custom AMIs vs Trad Conf Mgmt, Language dependency parser, d3, App Stores,

Migrating MongoDB to Cassandra, Solr Cloud, Core.async, AngularJs, Structural search in chrome debugger, CloudFoundry, Amazon VPC, Managing multiple teams' backlogs,

Pebble Smart Watch, Monads, Gestures with Angular, ClojureScript, Dev Ops Intro, Cynefin and testing, Appstore apps for fun and profit, Generative testing, Software Engineering for CEOs, Docker,

Interpersonal Communication

name: Adelaide OpenData & IoT Meetup
description:
This Meetup initiated by the Growing Data Foundation will be covering topics around the Adelaide Node of The Things Network (an Open Radio network to connect the 'Internet of Things') and OpenData. It's purpose is to encourage collaborative usage of the network and sharing of the resulting data-sets.

If you're interested in or what to know more about open networked hardware, getting data from sensors and other devices over a longer range or just like playing about withOpen Hardware platforms. Programmers, artists, designers, academics, and business-types are all welcome. Find us at @growingdatafdt on Twitter and use #TTNADL to share.

Topics including (but not limited to): 

• Open Data (making data accessible via permissive licenses to promote sharing and re-use)
Sensors

• Internet of Things

• Storage of Open Data

• Analytics and apps

• Educational uses of OpenData and IoT

Please take some time to complete your group profile and introduce yourself to the group - enjoy :)

name: LoRaWAN Bristol
description: The LoRaWAN Bristol meetup is for everyone interested in using and contributing to the LoRaWAN Bristol Network - a low power radio network, based on thethingsnetwork.org, for he Internet of Things which will be rolled out across Bristol in the coming months. If you want to create nodes - sensors or other IoT things - or Gateways, this meetup group is the place to come to share your ideas and experiences.

next_event.name: All you wanted to know about RF, but were afraid to ask!

name: CouchDB™ Boston
description:
Relax, it's CouchDB! CouchDB Boston brings together developers, technologists, and anyone else passionate or curious about CouchDB to swap stories, share projects, code apps, and otherwise relax on the couch. All skill levels are welcome, whether you've got hundreds of nodes replicating petabytes around the world, or just heard about CouchDB when you found this page. Join us for good food, good folks, and good times :D

All events organized by this meetup group fall under the Apache CouchDB™ Code of Conduct and Diversity Statement.

Apache CouchDB™, CouchDB™ and Apache are either registered trademarks or trademarks of the Apache Software Foundation in the United States and/or other countries, and are used with permission. The Apache Software Foundation has no affiliation with and does not endorse, or review the materials provided at this event, which is managed by IBM Cloud Data Services.

name: Melbourne Kubernetes User Group
description:
For anyone doing, tinkering or looking at cool things relating to the Kubernetes project: http://kubernetes.io/

Kubernetes is an open source orchestration system for Docker containers. It handles scheduling onto nodes in a compute cluster and actively manages workloads to ensure that their state matches the users declared intentions. Using the concepts of "labels" and "pods", it groups the containers which make up an application into logical units for easy management and discovery.

organizer.name: Ken Thompson
organizer.bio: I'm the "Open Source Guy" at Microsoft Australia & New Zealand. Outside of work, I enjoy and like to think I'm a home handyman and automation guy... but my WAF rating says otherwise. I also spend too much time on my Retropie arcade!

next_event.name: Kubernetes - Training Micro-Dragons for a Serious Battle

name: λ# - Serverless Programming with .NET Core and AWS Lambda
description:
Welcome to λ#, the Serverless .NET Core on AWS Lambda community!

At MindTouch, we are passionate about serverless architecture. We invite you to join our community on a journey to discover and master .NET Core and AWS Lambda. Come meet us at the MindTouch HQ for pizza and tackle a new serverless programming challenge every month!

About .NET Core: .NET Core is a general purpose development platform maintained by Microsoft and the .NET community on GitHub. It is cross-platform, supporting Windows, OSX/macOS and Linux, and can be used in device, cloud, and embedded/IoT scenarios.

About AWS Lambda: AWS Lambda is a compute service that lets you run code without provisioning or managing servers. AWS Lambda executes your code only when needed and scales automatically, from a few requests per day to thousands per second.

BRING YOUR LAPTOP!

This is a hands-on meetup suitable for advanced developers, passionate beginners, and curious minds! Each meeting is focused on exploring a specific technology by building a service with it. Participants are split into random teams of 3 to 4 to collaborate on a solution. We believe that team collaboration is the most fun way to make new discoveries, master new technologies, and make new friends!

Mentors are available to answer questions and guide each group to a solution. This is a great event to meet experienced engineers, build cutting edge services, and mingle with like-minded technologists who are passionate about serverless architecture!

COME PREPARED!

We’ll be using the same tools for each meetup. To avoid any delays getting started with the programming challenge, make sure to install them ahead of time:

AWS Tools

• Sign-up for an AWS Account

• Install AWS CLI

.NET Core

• Install .NET Core 1.0

• Install VS Code

• Install C# Extension for VS Code

AWS C# Lambda Tools

• Install Node.js

• Install Yeoman

• Install AWS C# Lambda generator:

npm install -g yo generator-aws-lambda-dotnet

WHAT TO EXPECT!

6:00 - 6:30 Mix & Mingle

6:30 - 7:00 See Challenge Presentation

7:00 - 7:15 Join Random Team

7:15 - 8:15 Begin Team Hackathon

8:15 - 8:30 Break for Stretching & Sharing

8:30 - 9:30 Continue Team Hackathon

9:30 - 10:00 Present & Share Insights

next_event.name: Team Hackathon: Serverless Web-Crawler with AWS Lambda, DynamoDB & .NET Core

name: Build With Code - Downtown LA
description:
Build with Code hosts free weekly JavaScript and Software Engineering workshops, lectures and pair-programming sessions. Welcome! 

Learn and build with the hard parts of JavaScript every week, 6:30pm-8:00pm through intuitive lectures and pair-programming

The reason people who only watch programming videos don't become programmers is because they're not programming. Come join other aspiring engineers and start building!

In JavaScript the Hard Parts, we cover callbacks, higher-order functions (functional programming with JavaScript), object-oriented programming with JavaScript, closure, scope and execution context

Hosted at Opodz every other week on Tuesdays 6:30pm-8:00pm and taught by software engineer and instructor Jared Fowler

Price: Always free

Codesmith (Codesmith) Codesmith teaches full stack software engineering in JavaScript through a 12 week immersive program. We teach computer science, object-oriented JavaScript, React, Angular, Node, distributed systems and mobile development so our grads can secure mid-to-senior level software engineering positions or launch their own ventures

Apply to the program at codesmith.io/apply. For further questions email admissions@codesmith.io

---

JavaScript the Hard Parts is a free workshop series in Los Angeles designed to teach pair programming and essential programming in JavaScript - including callbacks, higher order functions (like how to understand map, reduce, filter and foreach), closure, object-oriented programming in JavaScript and other topics

next_event.name: JavaScript - Understanding the Hard Parts: Closure, Scope, & Execution Context

name: La Capsule Academy - Paris
description:
Notre ADN? Démocratiser le code! 

Nous souhaitons apporter une vision technique aux professionnels d'aujourd'hui pour mieux les armer face à leurs challenges.

 Entrepreneurs, porteurs de projets, graphiste, chef d'entreprise, chargé de projet et responsable marketing, vous avez envie d’en connaître un peu plus sur le code et les fondamentaux du web ?

Ou vous êtes en reconversion professionnelle et souhaitez devenir développeur web?

La Capsule Academy, une école de formation intensive au code vous propose des coding bootcamps pour vous former efficacement.

Apportez vos ordis et venez découvrir les fondamentaux du web, HTML, CSS et la puissance et la simplicité de Javascript ou encore Node.js. Découvrez comment réaliser rapidement des pages responsives avec Bootstrap. Nous allons également vous expliquer ce qu’est une API en les manipulant au travers d’exemples concrets : connexion avec Facebook, Google map, envoi d’email avec Mailchimp…

Explication, démo live et exercice pratique sont au programme. On vous attend !

next_event.name: Apero découverte #4 Envie d'apprendre à coder ? Rejoignez-nous !
